verses.verse: Thanksgiving for Vindication A Psalm. A Song for the Sabbath Day. (Ps 147.1) It is good to give thanks to the LORD, to sing praises to your name, O Most High,
(Ps 89.1) to declare your steadfast love in the morning and your faithfulness by night,
(2 Chr 23.5; Ps 33.2) to the music of the lute and the harp, to the melody of the lyre.
For you, O LORD, have made me glad by your work; at the works of your hands I sing for joy.
(Ps 40.5; Isa 28.29; Rom 11.33) How great are your works, O LORD! Your thoughts are very deep!
The dullard cannot know; the stupid cannot understand this:
(Ps 37.38; 90.5; 93.4; 94.4) though the wicked sprout like grass and all evildoers flourish, they are doomed to destruction forever,
(Ps 83.18) but you, O LORD, are on high forever.
(Ps 68.1; 89.10) For your enemies, O LORD, for your enemies shall perish; all evildoers shall be scattered.
But you have exalted my horn like that of the wild ox; you have anointed me with fresh oil.
(Ps 54.7; 59.10) My eyes have seen the downfall of my enemies; my ears have heard the doom of my evil assailants.
(Ps 52.8; 104.16; Isa 65.22; Hos 14.5, 6) The righteous flourish like the palm tree and grow like a cedar in Lebanon.
They are planted in the house of the LORD; they flourish in the courts of our God.
(Isa 37.31) In old age they still produce fruit; they are always green and full of sap,
(Deut 32.4; Ps 25.8; Rom 9.14) showing that the LORD is upright; he is my rock, and there is no unrighteousness in him.
